description: Borrowed from Yiddish דריידל‎ (dreydl, “dreidel; spinning top”), probably a blend of דרייען‎ (dreyen, “to spin; to turn; to twist”) +‎ טרענדל‎ (trendl, “(dated) dreidel; spinning top”). דרייען (dreyen) is derived from Old High German drāen (“to turn; to twist”), from Proto-Germanic *þrēaną (“to turn; to twist”), from Proto-Indo-European *terh₁- (“to turn; to rub; to drill, pierce”); and טרענדל (trendl) is derived from Middle High German trendel (“spinning top”), from Proto-Germanic *trandijaną (“to revolve, spin”).

entries.meaning: A four-sided spinning top, inscribed with the four Hebrew letters נ‎ (nun), ג‎ (gimel), ה‎ (hey), and ש‎ (shin) (or פ‎ (pey)) on each side, often used to play a traditional game during the Jewish festival of Hanukkah.
A gambling game played using this top.
